description: From Middle English laththe, laþþe, earlier lathe, laþe, altered from Old English lætt (“lath”), from Proto-Germanic *lattō, *laþþō (compare Dutch lat, German Latte) from Proto-Indo-European *(s)lat- (compare Welsh llath (“rod, wand, yard”)).

entries.meaning: A thin, narrow strip, fastened to the rafters, studs, or floor beams of a building, for the purpose of supporting a covering of tiles, plastering, etc.
examples: The rubble waits him, sloping up to broken rear walls in a clogging, an openwork of laths pointlessly chevroning-flooring, furniture, glass, chunks of plaster, long tatters of wallpaper, split and shattered joists […].

entries.meaning: (geology, petrology) Microscopic, needle-like crystals, usually of plagioclase feldspar, in a glassy groundmass

verbs.description: lath (third-person singular simple present laths, present participle lathing, simple past and past participle lathed)

entries.meaning: to cover or line with laths
